body: Marshal Greenberg is an odd, unlikely whistle-blower. The son of an accused organized crime associate, he earned more than $100,000 a year operating the elevator that ferried workers and supplies up and down the exterior of the former Deutsche Bank building during its troubled demolition. He was hefty and heavily tattooed, a middle-aged man with a
title: A Whistle-Blower Say His Concerns About Safety Were Met With Scorn

body: To Carol Schlossman, Wachovia is a four-letter word. ''I had very good credit -- until Wachovia,'' she said recently as she rifled through a folder of papers, souvenirs of her dizzying odyssey through the subprime mortgage meltdown. In 1998, her cousin, Arthur Schlossman, now 66, bought a two-family house in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, for $240,000
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Finding a Surprise After Refinancing a Mortgage

body: Day after day, night after night, Francisco Hernandez Jr. rode the subway. He had a MetroCard, $10 in his pocket and a book bag on his lap. As the human tide flowed and ebbed around him, he sat impassively, a gangly 13-year-old boy in glasses and a red hoodie, speaking to no one. After getting in trouble in class in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and
title: Scared and Silent, Runaway, 13, Spent 11 Days in the Subways

body: Suzanne Kaplan did not become homeless overnight. It happened gradually, beginning in 1993 with her mother's death and becoming more or less a permanent condition four years later. Ms. Kaplan, now 59, has found shelter where she could: friends' couches, hospital emergency rooms, bus stop benches. Until recently she was steadfast in her refusal to
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; For Her, the Long and Winding Road Led to the Street

body: Want a swine flu vaccination at a free clinic this weekend? Get in line. The seven city-sponsored weekend clinics for swine flu vaccinations were reporting sharply higher volume than last weekend, particularly at the location on the Upper East Side. City officials said that as of 1 p.m. Saturday, 3,561 people were vaccinated -- more than half of
title: Long Lines to Get Free Swine Flu Shot in New York City

body: Many seaside towns make much of their location. Their shops are gussied up with nautical d√©cor -- rigging, buoys, mounted fish -- and their restaurants often have the word ''captain'' in the name. The Brooklyn enclave of Sheepshead Bay avoids this waterfront kitsch. Yes, there are boats and bait shops and plenty of fishing, but there are also
title: LOCAL STOP | SHEEPSHEAD BAY; A Seaside Enclave, Without the Kitsch

body: In Sheepshead Bay, the fruits of the sea, at the table or at the end of your line.
title: By the Bay in Brooklyn

body: BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real
title: When Love Is a Schlep

body: HOBBY'S DELICATESSEN & RESTAURANT in downtown Newark may have lost much of its more traditional clientele over the years, but it has held on to tradition. The corned beef and the tongue are cured for 14 days in stainless steel bins in the basement. The salamis hanging on the wall look as if they've been drying there, their flavor intensifying,
title: At Jewish Delis, Times Are as Lean as Good Corned Beef

body: A young man's long and fraught history with an ex-girlfriend came to a violent end in Brooklyn on Saturday, when he was fatally shot by the police after an all-day siege that began with a kidnapping, the police said. The police said officers shot Samuel White, 20, when he lunged at them with a knife in his small, second-floor apartment at 607
title: Brooklyn Man Is Shot to Death by Police in Standoff

body: SPOKES: THE PATHS Beckoned, So He Took Them All Comfortable in the shock-absorbing seat of his $120 Huffy mountain bike, Paul Kronenberg ascended the Brooklyn side of the Manhattan Bridge at a leisurely pace. It was two months after he began his seemingly quixotic summer-long quest to ride all the bike paths in the city, and the end was near:
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: THE BELIEVER Ojeda Hall-Phillips, 38, works seven days a week as a community organizer and youth minister in Queens. As a gifted student, she received scholarships and internships that helped her gain admission to Harvard. After college, she worked for investment banks until she realized she had a calling to religious service. ''My mother would
title: One in 8 Million: New York Characters in Sound and Images

body: An electronics store owner who shot and killed two robbers in a gunfight regretted none of it but his scars. A pet store owner who did the same and briefly became a neighborhood hero closed his shop, moved on to other work and tried to forget. A jeweler spent the rest of his life wishing he had never chased after two men who robbed his Brooklyn
title: Slaying a Robber Doesn't End the Ordeal

body: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man chased down a 13-year-old boy with whom he had argued and stabbed him to death with a screwdriver in Sheepshead Bay on Wednesday, the police said. The man, Juan Reyes, of Avenue U, was charged with murder and criminal possession of a weapon in the attack on Miguel Saavedra, who died at Lutheran Medical Center shortly
title: Man Is Charged With Killing Boy

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: If you can teach guitar or chess, if you are very organized, if you have any talent in Web design or interior design, if you live in New York, there is no reason you should be paying for dry cleaning. If you have any of those skills, but never thought they would get your suits cleaned, you probably have not been spending enough time perusing the
title: BIG CITY; Seeking Goods And Services, No Money Necessary

author: Alexander Nazaryan is working on his first novel, ''Golden Youth,'' about Russian organized crime in Brooklyn.
body: It was Saturday morning, Louis Armstrong was growling a jazz standard, and sunlight sneaked in through golden-draped windows. Inside the Speakeasy, early risers found refuge from the humidity, awakened by pots of French pressed coffee and potent brunch cocktails like the Fire on the Bayou, a Cajun take on the Bloody Mary. From the kitchen emanated
title: BLOGOSPHERE BROOKLYN ON THE BAYOU; Weekend Chefs, Conjuring New Orleans

body: $1.77 MILLION 2632 East 14th Street Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn A health care management group has bought this newly built 7,250-square-foot two-story office building. Buyer: Accord Business Administration Buyer's broker: Arsen Atbashyan, Maximillion Realty Seller: 2630 Realty Corp. Seller's broker: Brian Hanson, Massey Knakal Realty Services
title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sales

body: Shawn Brown, 36, is no stranger to the cleaning industry. He once owned a coin laundry and currently runs a house cleaning service. ''I've always been in the service industry and I have two dogs of my own, so I knew how hard it was to keep a yard clean,'' said Mr. Brown, of Rosedale, Queens. ''I saw that there was a huge need for this type of
title: New York City: Branching Out

body: THEY said nothing could replace Mooney's Pub. For almost a year, they were right. The old bar, which had stood on Flatbush Avenue near Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights since before Brooklyn was fashionable, closed in a rent dispute last June, after a rollicking Saturday night when the air-conditioning broke and people crowded in anyway. The next
title: DISPATCHES; A Bar -- a Bar! -- Where the Pub Used to Be

body: TOFU TAKEDOWN In the spirit of two wholly American pursuits -- overeating and winning -- comes the Takedown, a cooking competition where anything goes. Held in bars around town, it pits a few dozen mostly amateur contestants against one another in battles centered on dishes like chili (above), salsa or cookies. There are judges, audience favorites
title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: As Cheap as Water Q.Eight ounces of Poland Spring (plus a nice plastic bottle) costs about a dollar. How much does the same amount straight from the tap cost? I mean, how much does it really cost? A. One two-thousandth as much, according to the city's Department of Environmental Protection. Both the mayor and the City Council have voiced their
title: F. Y. I.

body: New York City's public hospital system announced Thursday that it was cutting 400 jobs and closing some children's mental-health programs, pharmacies and community clinics that serve more than 11,000 patients. Alan D. Aviles, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, blamed reductions in state Medicaid reimbursement, a sharp
title: Public Hospital System Plans Cuts to Jobs and Services

body: THE thumps in the background formed a steady beat that complemented the light Trinidadian lilt of Twindexane Lares. Twindexane, a senior at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn, stepped away from her teammates and retreated to the side of the dance studio where her team was practicing for the inaugural double Dutch season of the Public Schools
title: THE VOICE; T, Her Name Is Twindexane

body: DEAR DIARY: (This is a true story; it took place in Sheepshead Bay this winter.) In Dunkin' Donuts this morning, an old lady wearing a tattered watch cap started speaking to no one in particular. ''I can't sleep at night. I have pains in my chest all the time. My leg hurts and my children do not love me.'' People waiting in line hid in their
title: No Headline

body: TO get the slightly battered convection oven for their new Brooklyn chocolate factory, Rick and Michael Mast traded 250 chocolate bars. The chocolate is as good as legal tender for Andrew Tarlow and Mark Firth, owners of Marlow & Sons, the restaurant and specialty shop that bartered away the oven. ''We can't keep it in stock,'' Mr. Tarlow said.
title: Now in Brooklyn, the 19th Century

body: In prison, far from the Brooklyn haunts where his name was scrawled in blood, Anthony Casso stews. He stews over old vendettas. He stews over betrayals of the flesh -- heart problems and prostate cancer. And Mr. Casso, the once fearsome underboss of the Lucchese family who is now serving multiple life sentences amounting to 455 years for murder,
title: French Connection Epilogue: Mob Boss Offers New Ending

body: Terrence Livingston, a senior at Great Neck South High School, won the 600 meters in 1 minute 19.48 seconds at the Mayor's Cup Hall of Fame at the Armory Track in Upper Manhattan. Sheepshead Bay scored one of its rare victories over Brooklyn rival Boys & Girls in winning the boys 4x200 relay in 1:28.79, a meet record. Boys & Girls also beat the
title: SPORTS BRIEFING | TRACK AND FIELD; Livingston Wins 600

body: POLLET--Henry, age 94, died in Atlanta January 23, 2009. Retired high school teacher and Chairman of the Biology and General Science Department at Sheepshead Bay High School, Brooklyn, NY, PhiBetaKappa graduate of CCNY, lifelong scholar of philosophy and evolution, and devoted advocate of progressive causes. Long-term resident of Brooklyn, NY, West
title: Paid Notice: Deaths POLLET, HENRY

body: James Brady, who helped start the Page Six gossip column at The New York Post, chronicled the doings of the New York power elite in columns for Advertising Age and Crain's New York Business and wrote a gripping memoir of his combat experience in the Korean War, died on Monday after collapsing at his home in Manhattan. He was 80. His daughter Fiona
title: James Brady Dies at 80; Chronicled the Power Elite

body: A committee of the New York State Board of Regents approved a proposal on Monday for the city's first Hebrew-language charter school, all but clearing the way for the school to open in Brooklyn's District 22 this fall. While the full board will consider the proposal on Tuesday, it is widely expected to echo the committee's approval. The school, to
title: Plan to Open Charter School For Hebrew Clears Hurdle

body: Nearly two years after a wave of protests over New York City's first public school dedicated to the Arabic language and culture, state education officials are expected to consider greenlighting a Hebrew-language charter school in Brooklyn this week. The school would open in the fall if it is approved, first by a committee of the State Board of
title: Regents Consider New Hebrew Charter School in Brooklyn

body: For years, they fought on the same side, like tag-team wrestlers, defending police officers who had landed on the other side of the law. Joseph Tacopina, a former prosecutor from Brooklyn, was the legal voice in the courtroom; the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association was the ever-present voice of unconditional support for its officers. Outside the
title: A Case That Will Test a Lawyer's Bond With the Police

body: THE ground just inside a fence near the Fulton Ferry Landing on the Brooklyn waterfront was bare last week, only pavement and packed dirt, but that state of affairs, like the rest of the site's history, was only temporary. Within a year, planners say, a grassy field will slope up to a hill overlooking New York Harbor to form the centerpiece of the
title: DISPATCHES; In a Dig for the Future, a Glimpse of the Past

body: A 61-year-old livery-cab driver was shot and killed while working in Coney Island, Brooklyn, on Wednesday morning, the police said. It is believed to be the first killing of an on-duty livery driver since 2006, said Fernando A. Mateo, the spokesman for the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, which says it has about 22,000 members, including
title: Cabbie Is Shot to Death On Duty in Coney Island
